title: Return and Loyalty
shortSummary: Ruth Chapter 1 tells the story of Naomi's return to Bethlehem after the deaths of her husband and sons in Moab, highlighting themes of faithfulness, loss, and God's providence. The chapter sets the stage for Ruth's remarkable loyalty to Naomi and her commitment to the God of Israel. This chapter emphasizes trusting God amid hardship and the blessings of steadfast devotion.
timeline: c. 1100 BC - Period of the Judges

keyCharacters.name: Naomi
keyCharacters.description: A widow from Bethlehem who returns from Moab after the death of her husband and sons, expressing deep sorrow but also faith in God's provision.

keyCharacters.name: Ruth
keyCharacters.description: Naomi’s Moabite daughter-in-law who demonstrates extraordinary loyalty by choosing to stay with Naomi and embrace her people and God.

keyCharacters.name: Orpah
keyCharacters.description: Naomi’s other Moabite daughter-in-law who initially accompanies Naomi but ultimately returns to her own people.

keyCharacters.name: Elimelech
keyCharacters.description: Naomi’s husband who moved the family to Moab during a famine and later died there.

definitions.definition: A temporary stay or residence in a place that is not one’s permanent home.
People from Ephrath, another name for Bethlehem, indicating Naomi’s and her family’s origin.
Meaning 'bitter'; the name Naomi adopts to express her grief and the hardships she has endured.
Women married to Naomi’s sons; culturally significant as family members who share in family loyalty and support.

outline.heading: Naomi’s Family Moves to Moab During Famine
outline.description: Elimelech and his family leave Bethlehem due to famine, settling in Moab where tragedy strikes with the deaths of Elimelech and his two sons, leaving Naomi a widow.

outline.heading: Naomi Decides to Return to Bethlehem
outline.description: Hearing that the famine in Judah has ended, Naomi resolves to return home, demonstrating hope and trust in God’s provision despite her losses.

outline.heading: Naomi Urges Her Daughters-in-Law to Stay
outline.description: Naomi encourages Orpah and Ruth to return to their own families, acknowledging her inability to provide new husbands for them, reflecting her humility and realism.

outline.heading: Ruth’s Declaration of Loyalty
outline.description: Ruth refuses to leave Naomi, pledging unwavering loyalty and faith in Naomi’s God, exemplifying covenant loyalty and faithfulness.

outline.heading: Naomi and Ruth Arrive in Bethlehem
outline.description: Upon their return, Naomi expresses her bitterness by asking to be called Mara, yet their arrival coincides with the barley harvest, symbolizing new beginnings.

application: Trust God’s providence even in times of loss and uncertainty, knowing He works all things for good.
Demonstrate steadfast loyalty and faithfulness to family and God, as Ruth did with Naomi.
Encourage humility and honesty about our limitations while still placing hope in God’s plan.
Embrace new beginnings with faith, even when past circumstances have been painful or bitter.

keyVerses.text: And Ruth said, Intreat me not to leave thee, or to return from following after thee: for whither thou goest, I will go; and where thou lodgest, I will lodge: thy people shall be my people, and thy God my God:
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures Ruth’s profound commitment and faith, serving as a powerful example of loyalty and conversion.

keyVerses.text: And she said unto them, Call me not Naomi, call me Mara: for the Almighty hath dealt very bitterly with me.
keyVerses.significance: Naomi’s expression of grief reveals the depth of her suffering, yet it also sets the stage for God’s redemptive work.

keyVerses.text: Then she arose with her daughters in law, that she might return from the country of Moab: for she had heard in the country of Moab how that the LORD had visited his people in giving them bread.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Naomi’s hope and faith in God’s provision, motivating her return to Bethlehem.
